sent: 3255 Tholen was discovered on 2 September 1980, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell's Anderson Mesa Station in Flagstaff, Arizona.
2449 Kenos was discovered by American astronomer William Liller at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile, on 8 April 1978, and named after Kenos from Selknam mythology.
9298 Geake was discovered on 15 May 1985, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell Observatory's Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona, United States.
12923 Zephyr was discovered on 11 April 1999, by astronomers of the Lowell Observatory Near-Earth Object Search at Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona.
161 Athor is an M-type Main belt asteroid that was discovered by James Craig Watson on April 19, 1876, at the Detroit Observatory and named after Hathor, an Egyptian fertility goddess.
3367 Alex was discovered on 15 February 1983, by American astronomer Norman Thomas at Lowell's Anderson Mesa Station, near Flagstaff, Arizona, in the United States.
12482 Pajka was discovered by Slovak astronomers AdriÃ¡n GalÃ¡d and Alexander Pravda at Modra Observatory on 23 March 1997.
31179 Gongju was discovered on 21 December 1997, by Japanese amateur astronomer Naoto Sato at his Chichibu Observatory near Tokyo, central Japan.
79912 Terrell was discovered on 10 February 1999, by astronomers Walter Cooney and Ethan Kandler at the Highland Road Park Observatory, in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, United States.
3564 Talthybius was discovered on 15 October 1985, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at the Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona, in the United States.
2937 Gibbs was discovered on 14 June 1980, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell's Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona.
7959 Alysecherri was discovered on 2 August 1994, by American astronomer Carl Hergenrother at Steward Observatory's Catalina Station on Mt Bigelow near Tucson, Arizona.
6709 Hiromiyuki was discovered on 2 February 1989, by Japanese amateur astronomers Masaru Arai and Hiroshi Mori at the Yorii Observatory in Japan.
( 184212 ) 2004 PB112 was discovered on 13 August 2004, by American astronomer Marc Buie at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile.
7835 Myroncope was discovered on 16 June 1993, by American astronomer Timothy Spahr at the Catalina Station in Arizona, United States.
13154 Petermrva was discovered on 7 September 1995, by Slovak astronomers AdriÃ¡n GalÃ¡d and Alexander Pravda at the Modra Observatory in the Bratislava Region of Slovakia.
3850 Peltier was discovered on 7 October 1986, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell's Anderson Mesa Station, near Flagstaff, Arizona.

11714 Mikebrown was discovered on 28 April 1998, by astronomers of the Lowell Observatory Near-Earth Object Search (LONEOS) at the U.S. Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona, and later named after American astronomer Michael Brown.
3996 Fugaku was discovered on 5 December 1988, by Japanese amateur astronomers Masaru Arai and Hiroshi Mori at Yorii Observatory in central Japan.
15017 Cuppy was discovered on 22 September 1998, by the Lowell Observatory Near-Earth-Object Search (LONEOS) at its Anderson Mesa Station, Arizona, United States.
7225 Huntress was discovered on 22 January 1983, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell's Anderson Mesa Station in Flagstaff, Arizona, United States.
This asteroid was discovered on 3 August 1998, by the Lowell Observatory Near-Earth-Object Search (LONEOS) at Anderson Mesa Station, near Flagstaff, Arizona, United States.
102 Miriam was discovered by C. H. F. Peters on August 22, 1868, from the Litchfield Observatory.
15415 Rika was discovered on 4 February 1998, by Japanese astronomer Akimasa Nakamura at the Kuma Kogen Astronomical Observatory in southern Japan.
1132 Hollandia was discovered on 13 September 1929, by Dutch astronomer Hendrik van Gent at Leiden Southern Station, annex to the Johannesburg Observatory in South Africa.
2920 Automedon was discovered by American astronomer Edward Bowell at the Anderson Mesa station of the Lowell Observatory on 3 May 1981.
7166 Kennedy was discovered on 15 October 1985, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell's Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona, in the United States.
130 Elektra was discovered on 17 February 1873, by astronomer Christian Peters at Litchfield Observatory, New York, and named after Electra, an avenger in Greek mythology.

2759 Idomeneus was discovered on 14 April 1980, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at the Anderson Mesa Station near Flagstaff, Arizona, in the United States, and later named after Idomeneus from Greek mythology.
34351 Decatur was discovered on 3 September 2000, by American amateur astronomer Loren Ball at his Emerald Lane Observatory in Alabama, United States.
NGC 5002 is a Magellanic spiral galaxy in Canes Venatici.
NGC 329 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 4633 is a spiral galaxy located about 70 million light-years away in the constellation of Coma Berenices.

NGC 2403 (also known as Caldwell 7) is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation Camelopardalis.
NGC 1090 is a barred spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.

NGC 7025  is a spiral galaxy located about 210 million Light-years away from Earth in the constellation Delphinus.
Messier 94 (also known as NGC 4736) is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Canes Venatici.

NGC 276 is a barred spiral galaxy located approximately 626 million light-years from the Solar System in the constellation Cetus.

IC 335 is a lenticular galaxy about 60 million light years (18 million parsecs) away, in the constellation Fornax.

NGC 481 is a elliptical galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 331 is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 3184 is a spiral galaxy approximately 40 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major.
NGC 681 (also known as the Little Sombrero Galaxy) is an intermediate spiral galaxy in the constellation of Cetus, located approximately 66.5 million light-years from Earth.
NGC 615 is a spiral galaxy seen edge-on located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 4314 is a barred spiral galaxy approximately 40 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 223 is located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 369 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 356 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 353 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
UGC 5692 is a Magellanic-type spiral galaxy located 13 million light years away in the constellation of Ursa Major.

The Black Eye Galaxy (also called Evil Eye Galaxy and designated Messier 64, M64, or NGC 4826) is a relatively isolated spiral galaxy located 17Â million light years away in the northern constellation of Coma Berenices.
NGC 143 is a  spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 4506 is a spiral galaxy located around 50 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 2841 is an inclined, unbarred, spiral galaxy in the constellation Ursa Major that exhibits a prominent inner ring structure.
NGC 345 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 688 is a barred spiral galaxy with starburst activity located 190 million light-years away in the constellation Triangulum.
NGC 4595 is a spiral galaxy located about 42 million light-years away in the constellation Coma Berenices.
NGC 335 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 191 is a spiral galaxy located in the constellation Cetus.
NGC 985 is a ring galaxy in the constellation of Cetus.
NGC 367 is a spiral galaxy in the constellation of Cetus.
NGC 166 (also known as PGC 2143) is a spiral galaxy located around 2.6 million light-years away in the constellation Cetus, with an apparent magnitude of 15.18.

Messier 99 or M99, also known as NGC 4254, is a grand design spiral galaxy in the northern constellation Coma Berenices approximately 15 megaparsecs (49 megalight-years) in distance from the Milky Way.
NGC 1015 is a barred spiral galaxy, at a distance of 118 million light years in the constellation of Cetus (The Whale).
NGC 360 is a spiral galaxy located approximately 103 million light-years from the Solar System in the constellation Tucana.
NGC 5714 is a spiral galaxy located 130 million light-years away in the constellation of Boötes (the Herdsman).
NGC 4945 (also known as Caldwell 83) is a barred spiral galaxy in the constellation Centaurus, visible near the  star Xi Centauri.

As Apollo 17 was the last of the Apollo missions, Harrison Schmitt also became the twelfth and second-youngest person to set foot on the Moon and the second-to-last person to step off of the Moon (he boarded the Lunar Module shortly before commander Eugene Cernan).
Aleksei Aleksandrovich Gubarev (Russian: ; 29 March 1931 - 21 February 2015) was a Soviet cosmonaut who flew on two space flights: Soyuz 17 and Soyuz 28.
Garrett Reisman was a member of the STS-132 mission that traveled to the International Space Station aboard Space Shuttle Atlantis from May 14 to 26, 2010.

Michael E. Fossum flew into space on board the NASA Space Shuttle missions STS-121 and STS-124 and served as a mission specialist of Expedition 28 and commander of Expedition 29 aboard the International Space Station.
Fei Junlong was the commander on the Shenzhou 6 flight that launched October 12, 2005, with NiÃ¨ HÇishÃ¨ng serving as flight engineer).
Andrew J. Feustel's first spaceflight in May 2009, STS-125, lasted just under 13 days.
Robert A. Parker was a Mission Specialist on two Space Shuttle missions, STS-9 and STS-35.
David M. Brown died on his first spaceflight, when the Space Shuttle Columbia (STS-107) disintegrated during orbital reentry into the Earth's atmosphere.
Mark Kelly flew his first mission in 2001 as pilot of STS-108, piloted STS-121 in 2006, and commanded STS-124 in 2008 and STS-134 in 2011, the final mission of Space Shuttle Endeavour.
In 1993, Ulrich Walter flew on board the Space Shuttle Columbia on mission STS-55 (Spacelab D-2) as a Payload Specialist.
Christopher Cassidy's first spaceflight was on Space Shuttle mission STS-127, and his second was as a flight engineer for Expedition 35/36, launched aboard Soyuz TMA-08M.
Ivanishin was the Commander of the International Space Station for Expedition 49.
Nicole Stott served as a Flight Engineer on ISS Expedition 20 and Expedition 21 and was a Mission Specialist on STS-128 and STS-133.
Rick Husband traveled into space twice: as Pilot of STS-96 and Commander of STS-107.
Yuri Shargin was selected in 2004, to be the flight engineer on the Soyuz TMA-5 mission to the International Space Station.

Oleg Kononenko has flown to the International Space Station four times, as a flight engineer for Expedition 17 aboard Soyuz TMA-12, as a flight engineer on Expedition 30 and commander of Expedition 31 aboard Soyuz TMA-03M, as a flight engineer on Expedition 44 and Expedition 45 aboard Soyuz TMA-17M, and as commander of Expedition 58 and Expedition 59 aboard Soyuz MS-11.
Peggy Whitson was on her third long-duration space flight and was the commander of the International Space Station for Expedition 51, before handing over command to Fyodor Yurchikhin on June 1, 2017.
This was surgically corrected in 1969, and in 1971, Shepard commanded the Apollo 14 mission, piloting the Apollo Lunar Module Antares to the most accurate landing of the Apollo missions.
Vladimir Aleksandrovich Shatalov (Russian: ; born December 8, 1927) is a former Soviet cosmonaut who flew three space missions of the Soyuz programme: Soyuz 4, Soyuz 8, and Soyuz 10.
Valery Fyodorovich Bykovsky (Russian: ; 2 August 1934 - 27 March 2019) was a Soviet cosmonaut who flew on three space flights: Vostok 5, Soyuz 22, and Soyuz 31.
Alexander Misurkin flew aboard Soyuz TMA-08M on 28 March 2013 as his first space mission, and launched on Soyuz MS-06 as his second flight, in 2017.

Ellison Shoji Onizuka (, , Onizuka ShÅji, June 24, 1946Â - January 28, 1986) was an American astronaut and engineer from Kealakekua, Hawaii, who successfully flew into space with the Space Shuttle Discovery on STS-51-C.
Zamka piloted the Space Shuttle Discovery in George D. Zamka's October 2007 mission to the International Space Station and served as the commander of mission STS-130 in February 2010.
Christopher Ferguson was the pilot of Space Shuttle Atlantis on his first mission to space, STS-115, which launched on September 9, 2006 and returned to Earth on September 21, 2006.
Pamela Melroy served as pilot on Space Shuttle missions STS-92 and STS-112 and commanded mission STS-120 before leaving the agency in August 2009.
Soichi Noguchi's first spaceflight was as a Mission Specialist aboard STS-114 on 26 July 2005 for NASA's first "return to flight" Space Shuttle mission after the Columbia disaster.
Chris Hadfield was a member of this expedition until March 2013 when he became the commander of the ISS as part of Expedition 35.
Charles O. Hobaugh's most recent spaceflight was in November 2009, STS-129 on Atlantis again; this time he was designated Commander.
Randolph Bresnik first launched to space on STS-129, then served as Flight Engineer for Expedition 52, and as ISS Commander for Expedition 53.
Claude Nicollier's first spaceflight (STS-46) was in 1992, and his final spaceflight (STS-103) was in 1999.
Vitaly Ivanovich Sevastyanov (Russian: ; 8 July 1935 - 5 April 2010) was a Soviet cosmonaut and an engineer who flew on the Soyuz 9 and Soyuz 18 missions.
Meir launched on September 25, 2019, to the ISS onboard Soyuz MS-15, where Jessica Meir served as a flight Engineer during Expedition 61 and 62.
In 1991, Anatoly Artsebarsky flew aboard Soyuz TM-12 and docked with the Mir Space Station.
Gerst returned to space on June 6, 2018, as part of Expedition 56/57.
Abdul Ahad Mohmand became one of Soyuz TM-6 crew members and spent nine days aboard the Mir space station in 1988 as an Intercosmos Research Cosmonaut.

Polyakov completed Valeri Polyakov's second flight into space in 1994-1995, spending 437 days in space between launching on Soyuz TM-18 and landing on TM-20, setting the record for the longest time continuously spent in space by an individual in human history.
Fred Weldon Leslie is an American scientist who flew on the NASA STS-73 Space Shuttle mission as a payload specialist.

Frank Borman was the commander of Apollo 8, the first mission to fly around the Moon, and together with crewmates Jim Lovell and Bill Anders, became the first of 24 humans to do so, for which he was awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor.
Michael Fincke flew on one Space Shuttle mission, STS-134 as a Mission Specialist.
Svetlana Yevgenyevna Savitskaya (Russian: ; born 8 August 1948) is a retired Soviet aviator and cosmonaut who flew aboard Soyuz T-7 in 1982, becoming the second woman in space.
Anatoly Filipchenko flew on the Soyuz 7 and Soyuz 16 missions.
With a doctorate from the Russian Academy of Medical Science, Atkov was chosen to be the health specialist on board Soyuz T-10 and Soyuz T-11.
Vitaly Mikhaylovich Zholobov (Russian: ; born 18 June 1937) is a retired Soviet cosmonaut who flew on Soyuz 21 space flight as the flight engineer.
In 1968, Walter Cunningham was a Lunar Module Pilot on the Apollo 7 mission.
Wilmore was designated as pilot with five other crew members on Space Shuttle Atlantis for the mission STS-129.
Sacco flew as a payload specialist on STS-73, which launched on October 20, 1995, and landed at the Kennedy Space Center on November 5, 1995.
Norishige Kanai served as a crew member on board the International Space Station for Expedition 54/55, and returned to Earth on June 3 2018.
In July 2006, Frick was assigned to command the crew of STS-122.
Pyotr Klimuk's first flight was a long test flight on Soyuz 13 in 1973.
Michael S. Hopkins made his first spaceflight as a Flight Engineer on Soyuz TMA-10M/Expedition 37/Expedition 38, from September 2013 until March 2014.
Wing Commander Rakesh Sharma, AC (born 13 January 1949) is a former Indian Air Force pilot who flew aboard Soyuz T-11 on 3 April 1984 with the Interkosmos programme.
Viktor Ivanovich Patsayev (Russian: ; 19 June 1933Â - 30 June 1971) was a Soviet cosmonaut who flew on the Soyuz 11 mission and was part of the second space crew to die during a space flight.
Serebrov flew on Soyuz T-7, Soyuz T-8, Soyuz TM-8 and Soyuz TM-17.
Most recently, Kotov flew on the Soyuz TMA-10M/Expedition 37/Expedition 38 long duration spaceflight, from September 2013 until March 2014.
Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper has flown on two Space Shuttle missions, STS-115 and STS-126, during which she completed five spacewalks totaling 33 hours and 42 minutes.
Richard R. Arnold launched again in 2018 to the ISS, onboard Soyuz MS-08.
James Irwin served as Apollo Lunar Module pilot for Apollo 15, the fourth human lunar landing.
Rex J. Walheim flew three space shuttle missions, STS-110, STS-122, and STS-135.
Vladimir Aleksandrovich Shatalov (Russian: ; born December 8, 1927) is a former Soviet cosmonaut who flew three space missions of the Soyuz programme: Soyuz 4, Soyuz 8, and Soyuz 10.
Chris Hadfield first flew in space aboard STS-74 in November 1995 as a mission specialist.
Fred Haise is one of only 24 people to have flown to the Moon, having flown as Lunar Module Pilot on Apollo 13.
Poindexter was selected in the 1998 NASA Group (G17) and went into orbit aboard Space Shuttle missions STS-122 and STS-131.
John M. Lounge was a mission specialist on STS-51-I (1985) and STS-26 (1988) and was the flight engineer on STS-35 (1990).
Georgy Mikhaylovich Grechko (Russian: ; 25 May 1931 - 8 April 2017) was a Soviet cosmonaut who flew on several space flights including Soyuz 17, Soyuz 26, and Soyuz T-14.
Kondakova's second flight was as a mission specialist on the United States Space Shuttle Atlantis during mission STS-84 in May 1997.
Fyodor Yurchikhin served as Soyuz Commander for his fourth mission aboard Soyuz TMA-09M, as Flight Engineer for Expedition 36 and ISS Commander for Expedition 37.
Yuri Baturin's first spaceflight, sometimes called Mir EP-4, was launched with the spacecraft Soyuz TM-28 13 August 1998, and landed with Soyuz TM-27.
Alexander Misurkin flew aboard Soyuz TMA-08M on 28 March 2013 as his first space mission, and launched on Soyuz MS-06 as his second flight, in 2017.
Alan Bean was the last living crew member of Apollo 12.
Lawrence James "Larry" DeLucas (O. D., Ph.D.) is an American biochemist who flew aboard NASA Space Shuttle mission STS-50 as a Payload Specialist.
Vladimír Remek flew aboard Soyuz 28 from 2 to 10 March 1978, becoming the first and only Czechoslovak in space.
Dumitru Prunariu flew in space aboard Soyuz 40 spacecraft and Salyut 6 space laboratory.
Flew as Flight Engineer on Soyuz 22 and Soyuz T-2.

Rusty Schweickart was the Lunar Module Pilot on the 1969 Apollo 9 mission, the first crewed flight test of the lunar module, on which he performed the first in-space test of the portable life support system used by the Apollo astronauts who walked on the Moon.

After being selected as part of the first group of astronauts to include women, Margaret Rhea Seddon flew on three Space Shuttle flights: as mission specialist for STS-51-D and STS-40, and as payload commander for STS-58.
Wendy B. Lawrence was a mission specialist on STS-114, the first Space Shuttle flight after the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.
Randolph Bresnik first launched to space on STS-129, then served as Flight Engineer for Expedition 52, and as ISS Commander for Expedition 53.
Ovchinin made Aleksey Ovchinin's first spaceflight in 2016, and was assigned as Commander of Soyuz MS-10 in 2018.

Shannon Walker launched on her first mission into space on 25 June 2010 onboard Soyuz TMA-19 and has currently logged 163 days in space over one long-duration mission to the International Space Station (ISS).
Feustel returned to space on March 21, 2018 on Soyuz MS-08 with Expedition 55/56.
Soyuz TMA-18M was a 2015 Soyuz spaceflight to the International Space Station.
Progress M-29M is the final vehicle in Progress-M series, which was succeeded by the modified variant known as Progress-MS later in 2015.
The capsule remained docked to the space station for about five months until the scheduled departure of Expedition 45 in December 2015.
Progress M-28M (Russian:  -28), identified by NASA as Progress 60P was a Progress spacecraft used by Roskosmos to resupply the International Space Station (ISS) during 2015.
Soyuz TMA-19M was launched on December 15, 2015 from Baikonur Cosmodrome, transporting three members of the Expedition 46 crew to the International Space Station.
Soyuz MS-05 returned to Earth on 14 December 2017 after 139 days on orbit.
After six orbits, the capsule landed in the Pacific Ocean half a mile from the recovery carrier, and was hoisted aboard for Schirra to disembark.
The Soyuz spacecraft launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Tuesday, 7 June 2011 at 20:12 UTC (8 June 2011, 02:12  local time).
After three orbits, the spacecraft re-entered the Earth's atmosphere, splashed down in the North Atlantic Ocean, and was safely taken aboard USS Noa.
The ascent flight consisted of a Russian commander and two flight engineers from Denmark (ESA) and Kazakhstan respectively.
Apollo 11 returned to Earth and splashed down in the Pacific Ocean on July 24 after more than eight days in space.
The Vostok 3 and 4 spacecraft landed about 200Â km apart, south of Karaganda, Kazakhstan.
The sample was returned from Mare Fecunditatis.

Shepard and Mitchell successfully lifted Antares off the Moon to dock with the command module and, after a total of 34 lunar orbits, the ship was flown back to Earth where the three astronauts landed in the Pacific Ocean on February 9.
